elements.content: A series of mixed-ligand coordination complexes, namely, [Zn(L1)2(p-BDC)] (1), [Cd(L1)2(p-BDC)] (2), [Zn(L2)(p-BDC)] (3), [Cd(L2)(p-BDC)] (4), and [Zn2(L3)(p-BDC)1.5(OH)]·H2O (5) (L1 = 2-chloro-5-((2-(pyridin-2-yl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)pyridine, L2 = 2-(1-(pyridin-3-ylmethyl)-1H-imidazol-2-yl)pyridine, L3 = 2-(1-(pyridin-4-ylmethyl)-1H-imidazol-2-yl)pyridine, and p-BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Their structures have been determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural and show infinite chains which extend into two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular sheets by π···π interactions. For 3, L2 ligands link ZnII ions to form dimeric units [Zn2(L2)2] which are connected by p-BDC anions to form 63 layers which interpenetrate each other in a vertical manner to generate a rare 2D → three-dimensional (3D) polycatenated net. In 4, similar dimeric units [Cd2(L2)2] formed by L2 ligands and Cd cations which are linked by p-BDC ligands to give a unique 3D 3-fold interpenetrated (10,3)-b network structure. In 5, two kinds of p-BDC ligands coordinate to Zn cations to form a 2-fold interpenetrating network with α-Po topological structure, in which each L3 ligand coordinates to a Zn ion acting as a terminal ligand. By careful inspection of the structures of 1−5, we believe that the coordination geometries of metal centers and different substituent groups of N-donor ligands adopting various coordination modes are crucial factors for the formation of the different structures. The photoluminescent properties of L1−L3 and 1−5 have been studied in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: A series of mixed-ligand coordination complexes have been synthesized based on zinc(II) and cadmium(II), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and three kinds of (pyridyl)imidazole derivatives under hydrothermal conditions. It is found that the coordination geometries of metal centers and the N-donor ligands with different substituent groups adopting various coordination modes have significant effects on the structures of the coordination polymers.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) are rapidly increasing because of their wide potential applications as functional materials and their intriguing structures. However, the rational design and synthesis of MOFs with unique structure and function still remain a long-term challenge. The resultant structural framework is frequently influenced by various factors such as medium, pH value of solution, temperature, the nature of metal ions, coordination geometry, and number of coordination donors provided by organic ligands. Among the reported studies, organic ligands with carboxylate groups are especially interesting not only because of their various coordination modes to metal ions, resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites allowing for the large diversity of topologies, but also because of their abilities to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble various supramolecular structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are rapidly increasing because of their wide potential applications as functional materials and their intriguing structures. However, the rational design and synthesis of MOFs with unique structure and function still remain a long-term challenge. The resultant structural framework is frequently influenced by various factors such as medium, pH value of solution, temperature, the nature of metal ions, coordination geometry, and number of coordination donors provided by organic ligands. Among the reported studies, organic ligands with carboxylate groups are especially interesting not only because of their various coordination modes to metal ions, resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites allowing for the large diversity of topologies, but also because of their abilities to act as H-bond acceptors and donors to assemble various supramolecular structures.

elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of the Ligands L1-L3

elements.content: On the other hand, the nitrogen-donor ligands have been intensely investigated as auxiliary ligands for the construction of novel MOFs, and the use of auxiliary ligands is an effective method owing to the fact that they can satisfy and even mediate the coordination needs of the metal centers and consequently generate more meaningful architectures. To date, many polymeric frameworks using aromatic carboxylates, metal ions, and nitrogen-donor ligands have been reported. However, systematic investigation of the influence of the substituent groups of N-donor ligands on the formation of coordination frameworks is scarce so far. Thus, we focus our attention on a series of nitrogenous ligands and design four new N-donor ligands with different substituent groups based on 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole: 2-chloro-5-((2-(pyridin-2-yl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)pyridine (L1), 2-(1-(pyridin-3-ylmethyl)-1H-imidazol-2-yl)pyridine (L2), and 2-(1-(pyridin-4-ylmethyl)-1H-imidazol-2-yl)pyridine (L3). Compared with the typical N-donor ligands, such as 2,2′-bipyridine, 1,10-phenanthroline, and 4,4′-bipyridine, one of the structural features of these ligands are asymmetry ligands, which can act as both chelate and bridging ligands. In addition, L1−L3 with different substituent groups can display various coordination modes with two N atoms from 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole and N or O atoms from substituent groups. The hindrance and competition among these functional groups can result in novel multidimensional frameworks.

elements.content: Well-known d10 metal ions, such as ZnII and CdII, have attracted considerable attention not only because they exhibit appealing structures but also because of their good luminescent properties. Therefore, systematic studies have been carried out in our laboratory using reactions of the ZnII and CdII salts, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (p-BDC) together with a series of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole derivatives to investigate the influence of multicarboxylate and different substituent groups of N-donor ligands on framework construction and properties. Five mixed-ligand coordination complexes, namely, [Zn(L1)2(p-BDC)] (1), [Cd(L1)2(p-BDC)] (2), [Zn(L2)(p-BDC)] (3), [Cd(L2)(p-BDC)] (4), and [Zn2(L3)(p-BDC)1.5(OH)]·H2O (5), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Their structures have been determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, and thermogravimetric analyses. By careful inspection of the structures of 1−5, we believe that the coordination geometries of metal centers and different substituent groups of N-donor ligands adopting various coordination modes are crucial factors for the formation of the different structures. The photoluminescent properties of L1−L3 and 1−5 have been studied in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content:
Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification; 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole was prepared according to the literature.

Syntheses of L<sup>1</sup>

A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (2.00 g, 50 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and then 2-chloro-5-(chloromethyl)pyridine (8.10 g, 50 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after stirring at 60 °C for 24 h, and then poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid of L1 formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield after drying in air. Anal. Calcd for C14H11ClN4 (270.72): C, 62.11; H, 4.10; N, 20.70. Found: C, 62.21; H, 4.15; N, 20.73%. IR (cm−1): 3099 (w), 1586 (m), 1564 (m), 1484 (s), 1458 (s), 1402 (m), 1339 (m), 1274 (m), 1145 (w), 1094 (s), 988 (w), 821 (m), 759 (s), 700 (s), 624 (w).

Found: C, 48.12; H, 3.79; N, 8.74.% IR (cm-1): 3440 (w), 3101 (m), 1682 (s), 1570 (m), 1507 (w), 1425 (s), 1284 (s), 1110 (w), 936 (s), 877 (m), 777 (w), 728 (s), 680 (w), 521 (m).

elements.content: The C, H, and N elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm−1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 700 °C under nitrogen. The emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer.

Physical Measurements

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1−5 were recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as rigid groups. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecule in 5 were located in a difference Fourier map. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1−5 are summarized in Table .

Structure Description of 1. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that compound 1 has a zigzag chainlike structure consisting of one ZnII atom, two L1 ligands, and one p-BDC anion. The crystallographically unique ZnII atom is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two distinct L1 ligands, and two oxygen atoms from two distinct p-BDC anions (Zn(1)−O(2) = 1.9456(13) Å and Zn(1)−N(1) = 2.0369(15) Å), showing a distorted tetrahedral geometry (ZnO2N2) (Figure a). The Zn−O and Zn−N bond lengths are all within the normal ranges. All L1 as terminal ligands coordinate to metal centers in a monodentate mode (Chart a). The p-BDC anion coordinates to metal in a bis-monodentate fashion to generate an infinite zigzag chain (Figure b). All chains are parallel in the structure (Figure c). Adjacent chains are linked by π···π interactions between imidazol and pyridyl rings with the mean centroid−centroid distance of 3.811 Å to give a 2D supramolecular layer (Figure d).

elements.clean_text: 2  The Coordination Modes of Three Kinds of Ligands

elements.content:
Structure Description of 2. Compound 2 is isostructural with 1 by only using CdII ions instead of ZnII ions ().

Structure Description of 3. In order to investigate the influence of neutral ligands on ultimate compounds, 3-(chloromethyl)pyridine group is selected instead of 2-chloro-5-(chloromethyl)pyridine group, and L2 is obtained. Using the L2 ligand, compound 3 is prepared. In compound 3, the ZnII atom is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different p-BDC ligands and two nitrogen atoms (position-3 nitrogen atom from pyridine and position-3 nitrogen atom from imidazole) from two L2 ligands, respectively, showing a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Figure a). Two L2 ligands as bis-monodentate bridges (Chart b) coordinate to two metal centers to generate a dimer. The extension of the structure into a 2D network is accomplished by connecting the dimers and p-BDC anions of which all the two-carboxyl groups adopt chelating bis-monodentate coordination modes. From a topological viewpoint, if double bridges from two L2 ligands are considered as one linker, and the p-BDC ligand as a linker, each ZnII atom is a three-connected node, the structure of 3 can be described as an hcb (63) net (Figure b). The void space in the single framework is so large that two identical 2D sheets penetrate one hcb net to form a unique 2D → 3D vertical polycatenated architecture (Figure c,d). According to previous documents, only a few examples of dimensionality increasing from 2D layers to an overall 3D polycatenated entanglement framework have been observed.

elements.content: Structure Description of 4. A different structure of 4 is formed under a similar hydrothermal reaction. As shown in Figure a, the structure of 4 contains one kind of unique CdII atom, two kinds of unique p-BDC anions, and one kind of unique L2 ligand. Cd cation shows an octahedral coordination geometry {CdN3O3} which is completed by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two p-BDC anions (Cd−O(1) = 2.236(5), Cd−O(3) = 2.280(5) and Cd−O(4) = 2.558(5) Å), and three nitrogen atoms from two L2 ligand (Cd−N(2) = 2.272(5), Cd−N(4) = 2.342(5) and Cd−N(3) = 2.467(6)). The Cd−O and Cd−N distances are quite similar to normal Cd−O and Cd−N distances. A pair of L2 ligands in the monobidentate fashions bridge (Chart c) adjacent CdII atoms to give a [Cd(L2)2Cd] dimeric unit, which is further linked by p-BDC ligands in the bis-monodentate and bis-didentate modes to give a 3D framework (Figure b). An interesting feature of this framework is the presence of 1D honeycomb hexagonal helical channels along the a-axis. Each hexagonal helix connects to six adjacent helices by sharing common edges (Figure c). The handedness of some helices is illustrated as black arrows, and the center dot defines the direction as inside of the page. Because the right- and left-handed helices are alternatively arranged, the whole net is therefore racemic (Figure d).

elements.content: To further study the structure, if two L2 ligands are considered as a double-linker and two p-BDC anions as single-linkers, the CdII atom can be looked as a three-connected node, and the structure can be classified as an unusual (10,3)-b (or ThSi2) net (Figure b). In order to minimize the big void cavities and stabilize the framework, the potential voids formed by a single 3D network show incorporation with two other identical networks, thus giving a 3-fold interpenetrating network.

elements.content: Structure Description of 5. When L2 is replaced by L3, a particularly fascinating 3D structure of 5 is obtained. As shown in Figure a, the structure of 5 contains two kinds of unique ZnII atoms, two kinds of unique p-BDC anions, and one kind of unique L3 ligand. Zn1 is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different p-BDC anions (Zn(1)−O(1) = 2.084(3) and Zn(1)−O(5)#1 = 2.124(2) Å), two nitrogen atom from one L3 ligand (Zn(1)−N(2) = 2.115(3) and Zn(1)−N(3) = 2.192(3) Å), and two OH− groups (Zn(1)−O(7) = 2.095(2) and Zn(1)−O(7)#2 = 2.135(2) Å), showing an octahedral geometry. While Zn2 atom exhibits a tetrahedral geometry which is surrounded by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from different p-BDC anions (Zn(2)−O(3) = 1.923(2), Zn(2)−O(6)#1 = 1.979(2) and Zn(2)−O(2) = 1.989(3) Å), and one OH− group (Zn(2)−O(7) = 1.951(2) Å).

elements.content: The most striking feature of 5 is that two Zn1 atoms and two Zn2 atoms are bridged by two OH-groups to form a [Zn4(OH)2] unit with Zn−Zn separations of 3.159 (Zn1−Zn1#2), 3.189 (Zn1−Zn2), 3.700 (Zn1−Zn2#2), and 6.144 Å (Zn2−Zn2#2), respectively, which are linked by six adjacent p-BDC anions to generate a 3D framework. Unexpectedly, the L3, as a terminal ligand (Chart d), decorates the Zn1 atom. From a topological view, if each [Zn4(OH)2] unit is considered as a 6-connected node, and p-BDC as a linkage, the structure of 5 is a α-Po net with the dimensional sizes of 13.403 Å × 13.403 Å × 13.932 Å (Figures b and ). In order to minimize the big void cavities and stabilize the framework, the potential voids formed by the single 3D network show incorporation with another identical network, thus giving a 2-fold interpenetrating network (Figure c).

elements.content: It has been considered that the N-donor ligands are good connectors in mediating and constructing MOFs with specific structure. From the above-mentioned structural descriptions, it can be seen that the L1, L2, and L3 ligands have great influences on the frameworks of the complexes. Because of the structural features and coordination behaviors of L1, L2, and L3, it is anticipated that the structures of 1−5 are various (Scheme ).

Because of the structural features and coordination behaviors of L1, L2, and L3, it is anticipated that the structures of 1-5 are various (Scheme ).

elements.content: L1−L3 ligands show similar structural features, and different coordination modes. In compounds 1 and 2, because the steric repulsion is formed by the Cl atom from methylpyridine group, neutral L1 ligand, as a terminal ligand, coordinates to one metal center with two nitrogen atoms from one (pyridyl)imidazole group. So compounds 1 and 2 show 1D chainlike structures. Different from L1, L2 ligands coordinate to two metal centers with bis-monodentate coordination modes to form [M(L2)2M] dimeric units in compounds 3 and 4, which are linked by p-BDC anions to extend to ultimate structures with different interpenetrating frameworks. In order to adjust the angle and flexibleness of neutral ligand, different substituent group is used to obtain the L3 ligand. Unexpectedly, L3 ligand is similar to L1, as a terminal ligand, and coordinates to one metal center with two nitrogen atoms from one (pyridyl)imidazole group in 5.
elements.clean_text: L1-L3 ligands show similar structural features, and different coordination modes. In compounds 1 and 2, because the steric repulsion is formed by the Cl atom from methylpyridine group, neutral L1 ligand, as a terminal ligand, coordinates to one metal center with two nitrogen atoms from one (pyridyl)imidazole group. So compounds 1 and 2 show 1D chainlike structures. Different from L1, L2 ligands coordinate to two metal centers with bis-monodentate coordination modes to form [M(L2)2M] dimeric units in compounds 3 and 4, which are linked by p-BDC anions to extend to ultimate structures with different interpenetrating frameworks. In order to adjust the angle and flexibleness of neutral ligand, different substituent group is used to obtain the L3 ligand. Unexpectedly, L3 ligand is similar to L1, as a terminal ligand, and coordinates to one metal center with two nitrogen atoms from one (pyridyl)imidazole group in 5.

elements.content: In all, three kinds of ligands with different characters and substituent groups adopt various coordination modes, which have significant effects on the structures of the coordination polymers. The successful examples of the five compounds confirm that it is a feasible method to construct coordination polymers with different structural types by introducing ancillary ligands.
elements.clean_text: In all, three kinds of ligands with different characters and substituent groups adopt various coordination modes, which have significant effects on the structures of the coordination polymers. The successful examples of the five compounds confirm that it is a feasible method to construct coordination polymers with different structural types by introducing ancillary ligands.

elements.content: From the structures of compounds 1−5, it can be seen that metal centers also play important roles on the frameworks of the compounds. Both ZnII and CdII ions have no crystal field stabilization energy because of their closed d10 electronic shells, when their complexes are formed. The coordination numbers of ZnII and CdII ions are mainly determined by the steric repulsion between different ligands. Since the radius of CdII ion is larger than that of ZnII ion, the coordination numbers of CdII ion in 2 and 4 are 6, which is larger than those of ZnII ion in 1, 3, and 5 (4, 4, and 4 and 6), respectively. Thus, the structural discrepancies between 3 and 4 may be attributed to the differences in the coordination numbers of ZnII and CdII atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of the Metal Ions on the Structures

From the structures of compounds 1-5, it can be seen that metal centers also play important roles on the frameworks of the compounds. Both ZnII and CdII ions have no crystal field stabilization energy because of their closed d10 electronic shells, when their complexes are formed. The coordination numbers of ZnII and CdII ions are mainly determined by the steric repulsion between different ligands. Since the radius of CdII ion is larger than that of ZnII ion, the coordination numbers of CdII ion in 2 and 4 are 6, which is larger than those of ZnII ion in 1, 3, and 5 (4, 4, and 4 and 6), respectively. Thus, the structural discrepancies between 3 and 4 may be attributed to the differences in the coordination numbers of ZnII and CdII atoms.

elements.content: Luminescent compounds are of great current interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1−5 and N-donor ligands L1−L3 were measured at room temperature (Figure ), and the wavelengths of the emission maximums and excitation are listed in Table . In comparison with the N-donor ligands, the emission maxima of compounds 1−5 have changed and show red shifts. It is possible that a combination of several factors together, including charge-transfer transition between N-donor ligands and metal centers, N-donor ligands coordinating to the metal centers, which effectively increases the rigidities of the ligands and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay, and a change in the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of deprotonated BDC−2 anions.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Luminescent compounds are of great current interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1-5 and N-donor ligands L1-L3 were measured at room temperature (Figure ), and the wavelengths of the emission maximums and excitation are listed in Table . In comparison with the N-donor ligands, the emission maxima of compounds 1-5 have changed and show red shifts. It is possible that a combination of several factors together, including charge-transfer transition between N-donor ligands and metal centers, N-donor ligands coordinating to the metal centers, which effectively increases the rigidities of the ligands and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay, and a change in the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of deprotonated BDC-2 anions.

Thermal Analysis

elements.content: The anhydrous compounds 1 and 2 begin to decompose at 232 °C for 1, and 230 °C for 2, and end above 616 °C for 1 and 638 °C for 2, respectively. The weight loss (found: 88.9% for 1 and 84.4% for 2) correspond to the loss of organic components (calcd 89.4% for 1 and 84.3% for 2). The remaining weight of 11.1% for 1 and 15.6% for 2 correspond to the percentage (10.6%) of ZnO in 1 and (15.7%) of CdO in 2, respectively. For compounds 3 and 4, the weight losses in the range of 182−526 °C for 3 and 207−476 °C for 4 correspond to the removal of the corresponding organic components, and the remaining weight corresponds to the formation of ZnO in 3 (obsd 17.3%, calcd 17.5%) and CdO in 4 (obsd 24.7%, calcd 25.0%). The TG curve of compound 5 shows a weight loss of 2.7% from room temperature to 80 °C, corresponding to the release of one water molecule (calcd 2.8%). The anhydrous composition begins to decompose at 270 °C and ends above 562 °C. The weight loss (found: 71.5%) corresponds to the loss of organic components (calcd 72.1%). The remaining weight of 25.8% corresponds to the percentage (25.1%) of ZnO.

elements.content: A series of mixed-ligand coordination complexes have been synthesized based on zinc(II) and cadmium(II), p-BDC, and four kinds of (pyridyl)imidazole derivatives under hydrothermal conditions. The fluorescent emissions show that the complexes may be good candidates for photoactive materials. It is found that the coordination geometries of metal centers and the N-donor ligands with different substituent groups adopting various coordination modes have a significant effect on the structures of the coordination polymers. It is a feasible method to introduce ancillary groups to the rational design and synthesis of metal−organic coordination polymers with specific structure and properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A series of mixed-ligand coordination complexes have been synthesized based on zinc(II) and cadmium(II), p-BDC, and four kinds of (pyridyl)imidazole derivatives under hydrothermal conditions. The fluorescent emissions show that the complexes may be good candidates for photoactive materials. It is found that the coordination geometries of metal centers and the N-donor ligands with different substituent groups adopting various coordination modes have a significant effect on the structures of the coordination polymers. It is a feasible method to introduce ancillary groups to the rational design and synthesis of metal-organic coordination polymers with specific structure and properties.

Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification; 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole was prepared according to the literature.

Syntheses of L<sup>1</sup>

A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (2.00 g, 50 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, and then 2-chloro-5-(chloromethyl)pyridine (8.10 g, 50 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after stirring at 60 °C for 24 h, and then poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid of L1 formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield after drying in air. Anal. Calcd for C14H11ClN4 (270.72): C, 62.11; H, 4.10; N, 20.70. Found: C, 62.21; H, 4.15; N, 20.73%. IR (cm−1): 3099 (w), 1586 (m), 1564 (m), 1484 (s), 1458 (s), 1402 (m), 1339 (m), 1274 (m), 1145 (w), 1094 (s), 988 (w), 821 (m), 759 (s), 700 (s), 624 (w).

Syntheses of L<sup>2</sup>

A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (4.00 g, 100 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, then 3-(chloromethyl)pyridine hydrochloride (8.20 g, 50 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature after stirring at 60 °C for 24 h, and then poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid of L2 formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 75% yield after drying in air. Anal. Calcd for C14H12N4 (236.27): C, 71.17; H, 5.12; N, 23.71. Found: C, 71.21; H, 5.15; N, 23.73%. IR (cm−1): 3108 (m), 1677 (w), 1588 (s), 1485 (s), 1460 (s), 1429 (m), 1369 (w), 1276 (m), 1190 (w), 1144 (m), 1094 (m), 992 (w), 794 (s), 708 (s), 621 (w).

A mixture of p-BDC (0.17 g, 1.00 mmol), L1 (0.54 g, 2.0 mmol), Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.22 g, 1.00 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2.00 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for 1 h and then sealed in a 25 mL Teflonlined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 150 °C and held at that temperature for 72 h, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C·h−1, and held for 8 h, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C·h−1. Colorless crystals of 1 were collected in 78.7% yield based on Zn(OAc)2·2H2O. Anal. Calcd for C36H26Cl2N8O4Zn (770.92): C, 56.08; H, 3.40; N, 14.53. Found: C, 55.87; H, 3.36; N, 14.55%. The container was heated to 150 °C and held at that temperature for 72 h, and then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C·h−1, and held for 8 h, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C·h−1. Colorless crystals of 2 were collected in 72.9% yield based on Cd(OAc)2·2H2O. Anal. Calcd for C36H26CdCl2N8O4 (817.95): C, 52.86; H, 3.20; N, 13.70. Found: C, 52.91; H, 3.15; N, 13.73%. A mixture of p-BDC (0.34 g, 2.00 mmol), L3 (0.24 g, 1.00 mmol), Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.45 g, 2.00 mmol), NaOH (0.08 g, 2.00 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for 1 h and then sealed in a 25 mL Teflonlined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 150 °C and held at that temperature for 72 h, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C·h−1, and held for 8 h, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C·h−1.
